Let me give you an example. Say that the Knesset passes a law saying that parties can only run for elections if they publicly affirm in writing that they will recommend the outgoing PM as the President's first choice to form the new government. Parties which refuse cannot run or, if they renege after the elections, have their votes invalidated.

Currently, the SC would rule that this is grossly unreasonable and conflicts with at least one basic law and strike the new law down. After the reform, then first of all, reasonablity is no longer a cause of action. Secondly, the court would need a unanimous vote from a 15-judge panel (currently I don't think that full-coutt panels are ever used) to strike down a law. Third, even if the law is struck down, the Knesset  can reinstate it with 61 votes (which the ruling coalition has by default).
